info.name: Tales of Mir Homebrew: Magical Armors, Weapons, and Items
info.description: A collection of magical weapons, armors, and items found by the PCs of the Tales of Mir campaign.
info.author: Salty Coffee

description.p: You have a +1 bonus to AC while wearing this armor.
Mithral is a light, flexible metal. A mithral chain shirt or breastplate can be worn under normal clothes.
If the armor normally imposes disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks or has a Strength requirement, the mithral version of the armor doesn't.

set.name: type
set.addition: medium or heavy, but not hide

description.p: You gain a +2 bonus to AC while you wear this armor. You are considered proficient with this armor even if you lack proficiency with medium armor.
In addition, when something attempts to move you against your will, you have Advantage on the ability check or saving throw to resist the effect.
A set of shadowy plate mail conjured from the Shadowfell to aid their Chosen in battle.

While armored in shadow, you cast no shadow, and you have Resistance to Cold and Necrotic damage. However, if you take either Fire or Radiant damage, or are targeted by a level 3+ spell that creates light, you must make a Strength saving throw equal to 10 plus the damage taken, or 10 plus the level of the light spell. On a failed save, the armor dissipates and you cannot re-summon the armor until after a short rest.
A set of shadowy plate mail conjured from the Shadowfell to aid their Chosen in battle.

While armored in shadow, you cast no shadow, and you have Resistance to Cold and Necrotic damage. However, if you take either Fire or Radiant damage, or are targeted by a level 3+ spell that creates light, you must make a Strength saving throw equal to 10 plus the damage taken, or 10 plus the level of the light spell. On a failed save, the armor dissipates and you cannot re-summon the armor until after a short rest.

This curious shield is shaped like a blooming lily, with the likeness of a terrified face carved into its center. While holding this Shield, you have a +2 bonus to Armor Class, in addition to the Shield's normal bonus to AC.

Curse. This shield is cursed to house the soul of a cowardly deserter of some bygone era. While you hold the shield, the soul within insists it hates pain of all forms, and begs you not to use it. Whenever you are subjected to an attack, the shield will scream in fear and terror, pleading that you shield it with your own body in order to protect it from harm. It is yet unknown what will happen if you do not acquiesce to its gutless cowardice...

element.name: Healing Potion of Hill Giant Strength

description.p: You regain 2d4 + 2 hit points when you drink this potion. Additionally, your Strength score is set to 21 for 1 hour. When agitated, the potion's syrupy greenish liquid glints with small flashes of phospholuminescence.
This potion was given to the human known as Barnacle by a servant of Ploink, the Goddess of Chaos. Its bright azure fluid smells of the sea and has a jellyfish-like bubble floating in it.

Upon imbibing this potion, you can breathe underwater for 1 hour. However, due to the nature of its origin, anyone who drinks this potion and was not its original recipient will cause its chaotic magic to manifest in potentially dangerous ways.

While attuned to this ring, the wearer can cast the Command spell on a target within range. The DC of this spell is equal to twice their spellcasting DC. Once the ring casts this spell, it cannot do so again until you finish a Long Rest.

Curse. This ring is cursed. Attuning to the ring transfers the curse to you until you are targeted by a Remove Curse spell or similar magic. As long as you remain cursed, you cannot remove the ring. Whenever you cast the Command spell through it, the spell will also target yourself or a random ally within range as a second target. They must succeed on the spell's saving throw or be subjected to the same command issued to the first target.
While attuned to this ring, the wearer can read, speak, and otherwise understand profanities and otherwise obscene gestures in any language.

Curse. This ring is cursed. Attuning to the ring transfers the curse to you until you are targeted by a Remove Curse spell or similar magic. As long as you remain cursed, you cannot remove the ring. While wearing the ring, you will involuntarily utter curses and profanities as long as you are conscious.
When speaking the command word, the wearer is placed under the effects of the Water Walk spell.

Curse. This item is cursed. Placing it on your finger curses you until you are targeted by a Remove Curse spell or similar magic. As long as you remain cursed, you cannot remove the ring. After having spoken the command word to activate its magic, if the ring is not submerged, it gains weight rapidly, pulling the wearer back underwater. This lasts until the ring has been dry for 1d10 minutes.

This wand has 10 charges. While holding it, you can expend no more than 3 charges to cast Magic Missile from it. For 1 charge, you cast the level 1 version of the spell. You can increase the spell's level by 1 for each additional charge you expend.
Regaining Charges. The wand regains 1d6 + 4 expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll 1d20. On a 1, the wand crumbles into ashes and is destroyed.

Curse. This wand is cursed. Each time you activate it, a small portal to an unknown location will appear somewhere within range, and one of the darts fired from the wand will streak off-target, disappearing into it. The portal will then vanish.

div.p: During the battle against the void-corrupted Madeline in the bowels of Dun'Morach, Alton High-Hill was granted an unexpected communion with his god Milil, the Lord of All Songs. The troubadour god imparted upon him the knowledge of the fluidity of fate—how his story, as well as those of his companions, had been inexplicably changed by forces beyond the mortal realm. However, the god urged Alton to embrace this new story, to make it one truly worth telling, and granted him this sword as a boon to assist to that endeavor.

description.p: You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This sword has 2 charges. When you hit a creature with it, you can expend one charge to add an extra 1d8 Radiant damage to the attack. The sword regains all expended charges after finishing a Long Rest.
Found buried within the bowls of the sunken Underkeep of Dun'Morach, this finely-crafted battleaxe gleams with a golden sheen and is inset with glittering rubies.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Additionally, this weapon ignores defenses and Resistances granted by rock or stone; for example, an Earth Elemental would not have Resistance to this weapon's damage, and its natural Armor Class would be reduced to 10 plus its Dexterity modifier.

This magic weapon grants a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with it. In addition, the weapon has the thrown property with a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet. When used to make a ranged attack, it returns to the wielder’s hand immediately after a hit, but the wielder must use a bonus action to recall it should the attack miss.

div.p: While sporting no particular markings or embellishments, those of the Order of the Wardens would recognize this magical halberd as the signature weapon of Warden Riel. Known for his courageous acts of selflessness in his later years, this weapon embodies a more youthful bravado and vigor, and its blade gleams faintly when held by another of the Order.

description.p: The first time you attack with this halberd on each of your turns, you can reduce your Armor Class to grant the weapon a bonus to attack and damage rolls equal to the amount sacrificed, up to a maximum of +3. For example, you could reduce your Armor Class by 2 in order to gain a +2 to attack and damage rolls. The adjusted bonuses remain in effect until the start of your next turn, at which your Armor Class is returned to its previous value and the weapon loses any attack and damage bonuses.

div.p: This unique halberd is an exquisite marvel of blacksmithing. Crafted from two separate weapons—Themor's personal throwing halberd and the fabled battleaxe of King Mordon Grimlock—the blacksmith was able to retain both magical enchantments and meld them into a single, powerful weapon worthy of being wielded by a god.

description.p: This magic weapon grants a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with it. Additionally, this weapon ignores defenses and Resistances granted by rock or stone; for example, an Earth Elemental would not have Resistance to this weapon's damage, and its natural Armor Class would be reduced to 10 plus its Dexterity modifier.

This weapon also has the thrown property with a normal range of 30 feet and a long range of 90 feet. When used to make a ranged attack, it returns to the wielder’s hand immediately after a hit, but the wielder must use a Bonus Action to recall it should the attack miss.

p.i: "Dawn brings about new beginnings, new life, new chances. But what is a brilliant dawn without the dusk it must sweep away? It is a beautiful dance done by two."
~ The Ballad of Dusk and Dawn

description.p: This pair of weapons count as a single item for the purposes of attuning to them. The gilded mithral edge, stemming from the inscribed bone handle of Dawn glimmers like morning sun reflecting off clear water, and sings warmly as it splits the air. Its partner Dusk, crafted of obsidian steel, cuts with naught a whisper, and its blade is perpetually wreathed in wisps of shadow.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with these magic weapons, and you gain the effects of the Two-Weapon Fighting style while wielding both at the same time.

h5.u: The Duet of Dawn and Dusk

p.i: “For long time you lived alone in shadow, finally it is time to dance in the rays of the light, in a deadly dance meant for two.”

description.p: When you would invoke the magic of your Bladesong while wielding both of these rapiers at the same time, you can choose to reduce your maximum Hit Point total by any amount to invoke the “The Duet of Dusk and Dawn”. Infused with your own lifeforce, Dawn glows with a bright flash and Fairtale, the servant to Lathander, appears in an unoccupied space you can see within 15 feet. Wielding a copy of Dawn and Dusk held in opposite hands to your own, he has a number of Hit Points equal to the number by which you reduced your own Hit Point maximum, and all his other attributes, saving throws, movement speed, and AC mirror your own at the time of his summoning. Fairtale is an ally to you and your companions, and in combat he shares your initiative count and takes his turn simultaneously with yours. He obeys your verbal commands (no action required by you). If you don't issue any, he takes the Dodge action and uses his movement to avoid danger. The Duet lasts until your Bladesong ends, Fairtale is reduced to 0 Hit Points, or he moves more than 20 feet away from you.

Fairtale himself can not directly attack, but grants Advantage to any attack rolls you make with Dawn and Dusk against creatures within 5 feet of himself. Additionally, he can take one of the following actions on his turn:

ul.li: Blinding Flourish. When you make an attack against a creature within 5 feet of Fairtale, he will mirror the strikes. He does no damage, but can force the target to make a DC15 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature’s eyes are shrouded in shadow until the start of your next turn, during which their range of vision is reduced to 20 feet and they have Disadvantage on ranged attacks and Wisdom (Perception) checks. A creature with Blindsight or Truesight is unaffected by this ability.

Growing Shadows. If you do not deal damage to an enemy on your turn, Fairtale imbues your blades with radiant light. Until the end of your next turn, the next successful attack you make deals an additional 4d6 Radiant damage.

p.i: ““He fell once before, but it wasn’t the end. Everyone, yes everyone, should get a second chance”

description.p: If you or an allied creature you can see would drop to 0 Hit Points while the Duet of Dawn and Dusk is active, Fairtale can sacrifice his ethereal form to save them from such a fate. In a flash of brilliant sunlight, the target regains a number of Hit Points equal to twice Fairtale's current Hit Point maximum, and can immediately move up to their Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks. Doing so ends the current Bladesong, and you cannot perform the Duet of Dusk and Dawn again until you finish a Long Rest.

element.name: Amulet of Canine Transformation
element.p: This unadorned, weathered chain sports a heavy clasp and a simple pendant depicting a canine-like creature. Upon being clasped around the neck of a creature, that creature must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be polymorphed into a dog. The creature can repeat the save at dawn of the next day until they succeed on the saving throw. While transformed, the creature retains its mental statistics, but cannot write, speak, use weapons or items, or cast any spells.
If the chain is broken or removed forcefully before the creature succeeds on its Wisdom saving throw, it takes 1d10 Psychic damage before reverting to its original form.

description.p: A simple silver chain adorned with a diamond-shaped pendant with a small amethyst set in the center. While attuned to the amulet, you can summon a spectral homunculus that will obey your commands and, to the best of its ability, complete simple tasks for 1 hour. Once the homunculus has been summoned, it cannot be summoned again until you finish a Long Rest.

This brilliant silver amulet, shaped like an ecphoneme, is adorned with a kaleidescope of dazzling gems, and possesses the soul of a once-valiant adventuring knight. Each day at dawn, the knight will task you with a noble quest; the scope and difficulty varies from day to day, but the knight is incredibly insistent that you complete his task before the next dawn, and promises a great reward should you do so.

Curse. This amulet is cursed. Donning the amulet transfers the curse to you until you are targeted by a Remove Curse spell or similar magic. As long as you remain cursed, you cannot remove the amulet. If you fail to complete the knight's quest before the next dawn, you will be stricken with a dire consequence. Removing the amulet once you have received a quest will also constitute a failure.

This simple cloak is made from light blue satin and embroidered with motifs of clouds and steam. While you are attuned to the cloak, you can use it to cast the Misty Step spell. Once you do so, you cannot do so again until you finish a Long Rest.

Curse. This cloak is cursed. Attuning to it transfers the curse to you until you are targeted by a Remove Curse spell or similar magic. As long as you remain cursed, you cannot remove the cloak. Whenever you cast the Misty Step spell through it, all gear and armor is left behind at the original location except for the cloak, which will hopefully serve to hide your now unmistakable indecency.

These well-worn seven-league boots are lined with an exotic quilted pattern of scarlet and azure fabrics. Once per turn, you can use a Bonus Action to increase your Speed by 30 feet. This increase lasts until the end of the current turn.

Curse. These boots are cursed. Attuning to them transfers the curse to you until you are targeted by a Remove Curse spell or similar magic. As long as you remain cursed, you cannot remove the boots. At the end of each turn you use the Bonus Action to increase your Speed, a debtor's receipt appears in your inventory for an amount of gold equal to the total number of feet you moved in that turn. This fine must be paid within 7 days' time to a representative of the Fae Court (which will appear when called). Failure to pay the fine within the alloted time, or any attempt to destroy or deface the debtor's receipt, will result in a serious consequence of the Fae Seat of Celerity's choosing.
While wearing this silver circlet inset with a single sparkling gem, you have Darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. The area is illuminated as if bathed in starlight.

As an action while holding this gem in one hand, you can grant yourself Tremorsense out to 30 feet. You retain this special sense for as long as you continue to hold the gem, but it fades once you are no longer holding the gem in at least one hand.

This version of Tremorsense can always sense those you are friendly with as long as they are within 30 feet. However, it can only sense unfamiliar presences—hostile or otherwise—once you have perceived the creature with mundane senses such as sight or hearing.

This incredibly fetching sailor's tricorne is lined with gilded silk and adorned with mother-of-pearl and elaborate silver embroidery. While attuned to the hat, your Concentration on spells you cast cannot be broken by damage.

Curse. This hat is cursed. Attuning to it transfers the curse to you until you are targeted by a Remove Curse spell or similar magic. As long as you remain cursed, you cannot remove the hat. While Concentrating on a spell, you cannot willingly end your Concentration on it, nor can you cast another spell that requires Concentration until the current spell has expired. The only way your Concentration can end is if the spell's duration expires or you are subjected to a condition which will end Concentration, such as Incapacitated or Unconscious.

A well-built spyglass, wrapped in a soft leather grip and made of a dark mahogany wood. This particular tool is imbued with a particularly potent abjuration charm that makes it impervious to any sort of damage.

A well-built spyglass, wrapped in a soft leather grip and made of a dark mahogany wood. This particular tool is imbued with a particularly potent abjuration charm that makes it impervious to any sort of damage.

A creature looking through this spyglass has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks to detect things that can be seen. In addition, the user can view magical auras while looking through the spyglass, as if under the effect of a Detect Magic spell.

element.name: Mammazon's Grocery Bag for the Everyday Wizard

description.p: This well-stitched velvet bag was a gift of good will from Quinn, the enigmatic tiefling betrothed to the Company of Heroes' guildmaster Gorven, as a sign of their newfound partnership with the mercantile syndicate known only as Mammazon. When in need of material components for a spell, you can whisper its name into the bag and it will appear inside in the next 1d12 minutes. Once you have placed the component's monetary value—plus a convenience fee of 10%—into the bag, the component can be withdrawn and used for whatever magical mayhem you wish to sow.

However, convenience is not without its limits. If you use the bag more than three times before completing a long rest, the convenience fee will rise steeply with each subsequent item procured. Mammazon is nothing if not a shrewd businessman, after all.

The weathered brown cloak lovingly maintained through the years by one of the famed Cursebreakers serves its original purpose as a comfort on cold nights and bleak days, though now has been imbued with additional properties by an artisan of no repute.
Functionally, it possesses the same characteristics of a Cloak of Protection, conferring +1 to AC and Saving Throws. It requires attunement to gain these benefits.

At night or when its wearer wills it, the earthen canvas alights into a gentle night sky full of stars. Prominently featured are three constellations, that of an Archer, a Chalice, with a Dragon motif wrapped around the shoulders. The hood also possesses a tiny astral elephant, constantly strolling across the cloth surface. The glow acts as 5 feet of dim light or 10 feet if fully illuminated.

These strange speckled beans hold within them the raw chaotic potential of Ploink, the Goddess of Chaos. When ingested, the DM rolls 1d10000 and enacts the effect listed on the Expanded Wild Magic table.

div.p: A claw-marked leaf-shaped pendant, edged with polished darkwood and dangling from a sturdy leather strap. It once belonged to the wild druid Kars, the last member of a reclusive druidic order which lived in seclusion to pursue their affinity for bestial transformations. Following his death a century prior, however, his spirit continued to linger within the grove, and was eventually corrupted by the growing influence of Faust. The dracolich's power transformed him into a twisted arboreal monstrosity consumed by hatred and enmity, and he began to siphon the very essence of the land in order to fuel the creation of an army of mindless undead. However, before his vengeful crusade could spread, he was cut down and vanquished by a passing band of adventurers, and this pendant was all that could be found of the unfortunate druid.

description.p: Once per day while holding or wearing this pendant, you can cast the Tree Stride spell. Once the pendant has been used, it can't be used to cast the spell again until the next dawn.

element.name: Flawed Pendant of the Silver Tongue

description.p: A thin golden chain adorned with a simple circular pendant with a smooth, curiously dull stone set in the center. While the pendant is on your person, you gain advantage on Charisma (Deception or Persuasion) checks. However, if ever you fail one of these checks by more than 5, the central stone will detonate, shattering the pendant in a spray of magic-infused shrapnel. Each creature within a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on the stone must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 6d6 Force damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success. If a creature has the pendant on their person when it explodes, it has disadvantage on this save.

This small, translucent crystal stores spells cast into it, holding them until a creature speaks the command word to release them. When released, the spell uses the slot level, spell save DC, spell attack bonus, and spellcasting ability of the original caster, but is otherwise treated as if the creature holding the crystal cast the spell.
This specific crystal can store a single cantrip.

This small, cloudy crystal resembles the spell-matrix crystals produced by Jerirag, but is currently in an unrefined state. It can still store spells cast into it in the same way as its refined counterparts, but the imperfect cut and luster of the gem results in some arcane instability.

When a creature attempts to imbue the crystal with a spell, it must make a DC 10 Intelligence (Arcana) check. On a success, the crystal accepts and stores the spell for later use, while on a failure the crystal refuses to accept the spell and the crystal crumbles to dust. However, if the check is failed by more than 5, the crystal detonates in a spray of magic-infused shrapnel. Each creature within a 5-foot-radius sphere centered on the crystal must make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw, taking 2d6 Force damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success. If a creature is holding the crystal when it explodes, it has disadvantage on this save.
This specific crystal can store a single cantrip, and disintegrates to dust after a successfully stored spell is cast from it.
